0618680004|4.0|Think about it! I remember that classic line from the movie Falling Down twenty years ago, starring Michael Douglas. And that's just what Dawkins is asking the average man in the street to do.<br /><br />He asks the reader to think about it, from the opening preface, when he states without religion we wouldn't have suicide bombers, crusades, no witch hunts, no gunpowder plot, no Indian Partition, no Iraeli/ Palestinian wars no Serb/ Croat massacres, no persecution of Jews as Christ killers, no NI troubles, no delibrate unecessary mutilation of male and female genitals, no honour killings, no Taliban, no public beheadings of blasphemers, no flogging of the female skin for daring to show an inch of it and arguably best of the lot no televangelists.<br /><br />Think about the worlds' best selling book by far - The Bible. Whether an atheist an evangelist a priest or a Rabbi one thing that everyone agrees with is that the errr... good book is something by which the practicing religious among us class it as just that- A good book, a book by which we should lead our lives based upon the morals and principles contained within the scriptures. Right? Well...actually no thank you. What Dawkins points out is that the good book and in particular the Old Testament is littered with appalling immoral acts either condoned or ordered by God, Moses and Abraham including murder, mass murder, genocide, ethnic cleansing, gang rape, rape and child rape. I kid you not, its in there, read it for yourselves. When Moses army massacred the Midianites he also gave orders to massacre the women who were not virgins. He then instructed his troops \\"But all the women children that have not known a man by lying with him, keep alive for yourselves'.\\"<br /><br />Dawkins book begs the question again and again why are people so hung up on the teachings of undefined authors and scriptures written so long ago. Why haven't we evolved on a religious front as we have evolved in literally everything else. Whether you believe in a God or not, you must answer that question.<br /><br />Don't worry, this book isn't an anti Christian rant, he lets every religion have it with both blazing barrels. Jews, Christians, Muslims, Hindus, Mormons... they all get it, there is certainly no bias whatsoever. And yet all he is asking the reader to do is to think of some of the plain ludicrous and ridiculous things we do in the name of religion. \\"The great waste of time and energy,\\" as Darwin once said.<br /><br />The book can be at times a bit long winded and focus too much on Darwinism. I wanted more when he analysed certain writings from the Bible, I wanted a little more on the Koran. But all in all the book is thought provoking and will stimulate many an argument across a dinner table or restaurant. For me it's a must read for anyone with strong religious beliefs and of course for the atheist still hiding in the closet. I challenge you to read it and not think a little more about the `Big Man' up there in the clouds, whoever your `Big Man' may be?<br /><br />As Dave Allan, the Irish comedian once said. \\"Goodnight and may your God go with you.\\"d or not, you must answer that question.    Don't worry, this book isn't an anti Christian rant, he lets every religion have it with both blazing barrels. Jews, Christians, Muslims, Hindus, Mormons... they all get it, there is certainly no bias whatsoever. And yet all he is asking the reader to do is to think of some of the plain ludicrous and ridiculous things we do in the name of religion. \\"The great waste of time and energy,\\" as Darwin once said.    The book can be at times a bit long winded and focus too much on Darwinism. I wanted more when he analysed certain writings from the Bible, I wanted a little more on the Koran. But all in all the book is thought provoking and will stimulate many an argument across a dinner table or restaurant. For me it's a must read for anyone with strong religious beliefs and of course for the atheist still hiding in the closet. I challenge you to read it and not think a little more about the `Big Man' up there in the clouds, whoever your `Big Man' may be?    As Dave Allan, the Irish comedian once said. \\"Goodnight and may your God go with you.\\"
